member.name: T:XmlPreprocess.DataSources.CustomReader
member.summary:
Dynamically invoke a custom settings reader, passing the name of a temp file the process simply needs to write CSV values into the temp file supplied XML Preprocessor will read the values from the CSV file and delete the temp file.
The placeholder in command line to use is "${tempFile}" Example: xmlpreprocess /i app.config /cx "powershell.exe -command CustomScript.ps1 -tempFile ${tempFile}"

member.name: M:XmlPreprocess.CommandLine.NormalizeAllFileArrays
member.summary: Splits files that may be semicolon delimited, make sure to call this before using the input or output arrays
member.remarks: This just allows a little more flexibility in how the inputs and outputs are passed, you can pass them with multiple /i f1 /i f2 /i f3 .. parameters or semicolon delimit (a la MSBuild) them with one parameter like this /i f1;f2;f3, or a combination /i f1 /i f2;f3 etc.

member.name: T:XmlPreprocess.Util.DirectoryScanner
member.summary: This class enables the use of wildcards to specify files to preprocess.
member.remarks: It would be ideal to plug in the DirectoryScanner class from NAnt https://github.com/nant/nant/tree/master/src/NAnt.Core, which would also enable recursive patters such as "**\*.config" but as I read it, the GPL library that NAnt is released under is incompatible with MS-PL license that XmlPreprocess is released under. So for now, in the interest of keeping things simple, this class simply scans a single directory.

member.summary: The file specifications for which to scan (ex: "temp\*.config")

member.summary: Properties container

member.name: M:XmlPreprocess.PreprocessingProperties.#ctor(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

member.name: M:XmlPreprocess.PreprocessingProperties.ReadFromFile(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Read an XML properties file
member.remarks:
Property file is in the following format (the element names don't matter, just the "name" attributes)
<settings> <property name="INSTALLER">TRUE</property> </settings>
Or optionally, you can include environments
<settings> <property name="Setting4"> <environment name="Default">setting4default</environment> <environment name="Local">localhost</environment> <environment name="Test">testserver</environment> <environment name="Integration">intgserver</environment> <environment name="Production">prodserver</environment> </property> </settings>

member.returns: true if the specified key contains key; otherwise, false.

member.summary: Gets the with the specified key. Case insensitive.

member.name: T:XmlPreprocess.XmlPreprocessor
member.summary: Simple XML file preprocesser.

remarks.para: These properties can be referred to within the XML file.

item.description: implicit property automatically defined whenever running under the xml preprocessor
Directory portion of destination file. Example: d:\inetpub\wwwroot\myweb
Name of machine. Example: vmspap02caa
Numeric portion of machine name. Example: 02
Machine OS platform. Example: Win32NT
Machine OS version. Example: 5.1.2600.0
Machine's system directory. Example: C:\WINNT\System32
Machine's current directory. Example: "C:\Installs
Gets the major, minor, build, and revision numbers of the common language runtime. Example: 1.0.3705.288
Gets the user name of the person who started the current thread. Example: EFudd
Gets the network domain name associated with the current user. Example: MyDomain
Gets a value indicating whether the current process is running in user interactive mode. Example: True
System date. Example: 8/5/2003
System time. Example: 9:50 AM
.NET Framework directory. Example: C:\WINNT\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v1.0.3705
Environment variables. Example: _ENV_PATH contains system's path environment variable.
LH: Initial release

LH: Enhanced match patterns so whitespace around macro comments does not get rendered. Made search algoritm more robust with some limited error checking for mismatched ifdef/endif). Fixed issue that else's and endif's were being searched for globally instead of only within the body of a single ifdef/endif pair.
LH: Added several useful built-in properties.
LH: Removed case sensitivity. Made macro resolution recursive (one macro can contain another...as long as it is not circular).

member.returns: The buffer with any dynamically bound properties replaced
